thread.title: Metallica bring WorldWired Tour to University of Phoenix Stadium
thread.title_full: Metallica bring WorldWired Tour to University of Phoenix Stadium

author: Ed Masley , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: Metallica bring WorldWired Tour to University of Phoenix Stadium
text:
This picture taken on February 3, 2017 shows Metallica's lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist James Hetfield as he performs during the opening of the new Royal Arena in Copenhagen. (Photo: NILS MEILVANG, AFP/Getty Images)
20 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Fresh from rocking the Grammy Awards with Lady Gaga and the Hollywood Palladium last night, the members of Metallica have announced a local date on the WorldWired tour in support of their sixth consecutive release to top the Billboard album charts, “Hardwired… to Self-Destruct.”
The show plays University of Phoenix Stadium on Friday, Aug. 4.
Tickets are $55.50-$155.50, going on sale at 10 a.m. Friday, Feb. 17, at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com.
Presale tickets will be available to Legacy Fan Club members beginning at 9 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 14, with presale tickets available to all Met Club members beginning at 11 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 14. Citi cardmembers can take advantage of a special presale opportunity beginning at 11 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 14, at citiprivatepass.com.
Each ticket purchased through official outlets includes your choice of a standard physical or digital copy of "Hardwired…To Self-Destruct." Fans should expect to receive information from Warner Music Artist Services on how to redeem their albums within 14 business days of purchase. Full details of how you can gift the album, should you have already purchased, will be given on the redemption page.
Avenged Sevenfold and Volbeat will be the main support acts for the tour run.
The WorldWired our played Singapore in January, inspiring a rave in the Straits Times. “There are rock bands,” their critic begain, “and then there are heavy metal showstoppers. Metallica on Sunday yet again proved their status as gods of metal, taking the 10,000-strong army of black-clad concertgoers at the Indoor Stadium on a two-hour music odyssey that dipped into enough of their new material without alienating the fans who were there to hear the classics.”
The review went on to note the stage-to-ceiling screens, the stunning laser lights and a set list that included six of 12 songs from their latest disc while drawing heavily from their mainstream-crashing black, self-titled effort and the seminal thrash of “Ride The Lightning.”
